3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.title: Bar/Line Plots

objectives: Create bar plots to display categorical data
Create line plots to display measurement data
Read and interpret information from plots
3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.subject: Mathematics

outline.direct_instruction: Explain that bar plots use rectangular bars to show data for categories. Demonstrate creating a bar plot by counting votes for 3 favorite fruits. Show line plots use X marks to display measurements. Create a line plot of student heights together as a class.

outline.independent_practice: Students survey classmates about favorite pizza toppings and create their own bar plot. They then measure pencil lengths and make a line plot of the data.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'How many more people chose pepperoni over cheese?' 'Which measurement appears most often?' Have students explain their reasoning.
outline.exit_ticket: Students draw a simple bar plot or line plot and answer one comparison question about their data.

3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.summary: Learn to read and understand data presented in tables and charts. Practice finding information and making comparisons.
objectives: Locate specific data in tables and charts
Compare quantities in different rows or columns
3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Show a simple table of classroom supplies. Ask: 'How many pencils do we have?' 'Do we have more pens or erasers?' Let students practice finding information.
outline.direct_instruction: Explain table structure: rows are horizontal, columns are vertical. Show how to find data by matching row and column. Demonstrate with a food preferences table: find Emma's favorite by locating her row.

outline.exit_ticket: Students answer 2-3 questions about a provided table without teacher help.

3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.title: Intro Probability (experimental)
3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.summary: Conduct experiments to explore probability. Record and compare outcomes from flipping coins, rolling dice, and using spinners.
objectives: Predict outcomes based on experimental data
3-mathematics-data-and-probability-stati.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Flip a coin together 10 times. Record heads and tails on the board. Ask: 'Will we get more heads or tails?' Why do we get different amounts each time?
outline.direct_instruction: Explain that probability is about likelihood. Even though a coin has two sides, we might not get exactly equal results. Show dice rolls or spinner spins. Record every outcome.
outline.guided_practice: In small groups, students flip coins 20 times and record results. Roll dice and make tally marks. Compare group results. Discuss why results differ.
outline.independent_practice: Students choose an experiment (coin, dice, or spinner) and conduct 15-20 trials. They create a chart or table showing their results.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'What happened most often?' 'If you did this again, would you expect the same result?' Have them explain their thinking.
outline.exit_ticket: Students draw a simple tally chart from their experiment and write one observation about what happened.

outline.hook: Show a clock face. Ask: 'What angle do the hands make at 3 o'clock?' Point to a right angle in the classroom. Have students find right angles around them.

3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-a.title: Area/Perimeter
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-a.summary: Understand the difference between area and perimeter. Measure and calculate these for rectangles, squares, and other shapes.
objectives: Calculate perimeter by adding all sides
Calculate area by multiplying length and width
Solve real-world area and perimeter problems
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-a.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Walk around the perimeter of the classroom. Count your steps. Then ask: 'How much space is inside?' Explain: perimeter is the distance around, area is the space inside.
outline.direct_instruction: Perimeter = distance around (add all sides). Area = space inside (multiply length × width for rectangles). Show examples with grid paper: count squares for area.
outline.guided_practice: Find the perimeter of a rectangle by measuring and adding. Find the area by multiplying dimensions. Do several examples together on the board.
outline.independent_practice: Students measure a rectangle and calculate both perimeter and area. Try different rectangles to see how changes affect each measurement.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'Does a bigger perimeter always mean a bigger area?' (No!) Have them test with different rectangles.
outline.exit_ticket: Given a rectangle's dimensions, students calculate perimeter and area. Write or draw which one is larger.

3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-c.title: Coordinate Plane (Quadrant I)
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-c.summary: Plot points on a coordinate plane using ordered pairs. Move and identify locations using coordinates.
objectives: Plot points on a coordinate plane
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-c.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Show a coordinate plane with one point plotted. Ask: 'Where is this point?' Explain the x-axis (left-right) and y-axis (up-down).
outline.direct_instruction: Ordered pair (x, y) tells location. Start at origin (0, 0). Move right (positive x) or left (negative x). Move up (positive y) or down (negative y).
outline.guided_practice: Plot points together: (2, 3), (4, 1), (1, 4). Name the coordinates of points already plotted. Play a game finding treasure at coordinates.
outline.independent_practice: Students plot 5-8 given points on graph paper. Then name the coordinates of points you show them. Create their own shape using coordinates.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'What are the coordinates of that point?' 'Is (3, 2) the same as (2, 3)?' Have them explain why order matters.
outline.exit_ticket: Plot 2-3 points on a coordinate plane and identify the location of 1-2 given points.

objectives: Describe transformations using direction and amount
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-t.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Show a shape. Flip it (reflection). Rotate it (turn). Slide it (translation). Ask: 'What changed? What stayed the same?'
outline.direct_instruction: Translation: slide a shape without rotating or flipping. Rotation: turn a shape around a point. Reflection: flip a shape over a line.
outline.guided_practice: Using cut-out shapes and mirrors, demonstrate each transformation. Have students copy and predict what happens.
outline.independent_practice: Students perform transformations on grid paper. Draw a triangle, then show it translated right, rotated 90°, and reflected.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'If I translate a square, is it still a square?' 'How is a reflection different from a rotation?'
outline.exit_ticket: Students identify the transformation shown and describe it (e.g., 'Slide 3 units right').

3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.title: Volume
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.summary: Measure how much space objects take up. Calculate volume of rectangular prisms using unit cubes and formulas.
objectives: Count unit cubes to find volume
Use the formula length × width × height
Solve volume problems with real objects
3-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Fill a small box with unit cubes. Count them together. Explain: this number is the volume—how much space is inside.
outline.direct_instruction: Volume is measured in cubic units (cm³, in³). Fill a rectangular prism with cubes and count. Or multiply: length × width × height.
outline.guided_practice: Build rectangular prisms with cubes and count the volume together. Try different dimensions. See how volume changes.
outline.independent_practice: Students build 3-4 different rectangular prisms and calculate volume by counting cubes and by formula.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'If I double the height, what happens to volume?' Have them test.
outline.exit_ticket: Given dimensions, students calculate volume or count cubes for a provided figure.

3-mathematics-number-and-operations-deci.title: Decimals (intro)
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-deci.summary: Connect fractions and decimals. Understand place value to the tenths and hundredths. Read, write, and compare decimal numbers.
objectives: Understand decimals as fractions with denominators of 10 or 100
Use decimals in real contexts (money, measurement)
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-deci.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Show a dollar bill and a dime. Explain: a dime is 0.1 dollars, or 1/10. Connect to decimal notation.
outline.direct_instruction: The decimal point separates whole numbers from parts. Tenths place is one position after the point. Hundredths is two positions. 0.5 = 5/10 = 1/2.
outline.guided_practice: Shade decimal grids to represent 0.3, 0.25, etc. Write decimals and fractions that match. Compare decimals: is 0.5 bigger than 0.3?
outline.independent_practice: Students write decimals for shaded grids. Compare decimal numbers. Use decimals to record measurements and money amounts.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'What is 0.7 as a fraction?' 'Is 0.25 the same as 1/4?' Have them explain.
outline.exit_ticket: Students write a decimal and its matching fraction, or identify the larger of two decimals.

3-mathematics-number-and-operations-frac.title: Fractions (concepts, equivalence)
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-frac.summary: Explore parts of a whole. Understand unit fractions, equal shares, and equivalent fractions.
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-frac.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Divide a pizza into equal slices. Ask: 'How many slices is the whole pizza?' 'If I eat 2 slices out of 8, what fraction did I eat?'
outline.direct_instruction: A fraction names equal parts of a whole. Numerator (top) tells how many parts. Denominator (bottom) tells how many equal parts total.
outline.guided_practice: Shade fraction models to represent 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, etc. Show equivalent fractions (1/2 = 2/4). Compare 1/2 and 1/3.
outline.independent_practice: Students shade models for given fractions. Find equivalent fractions. Compare fractions with same denominators.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'Is 1/2 bigger than 1/3?' 'Are 2/4 and 1/2 the same?' Have them explain their reasoning.
outline.exit_ticket: Students shade a model to show a fraction and write it, or identify equivalent fractions.

3-mathematics-number-and-operations-mult.title: Multiplication/Division
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-mult.summary: Understand multiplication as repeated addition and equal groups. Master facts and multi-digit multiplication.
objectives: Represent multiplication as equal groups or arrays
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-mult.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Show 3 bags with 4 apples each. Ask: 'How many total?' Introduce: 3 × 4 = 12.
outline.direct_instruction: Multiplication is repeated addition. 3 × 4 means 4 + 4 + 4. Arrays show rows and columns. 3 rows of 4 = 3 × 4 = 12.
outline.guided_practice: Create arrays with objects or drawings. Write multiplication sentences. Skip count by 2s, 5s, 10s.
outline.independent_practice: Students create arrays for given multiplications. Solve word problems involving equal groups.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'Is 3 × 4 the same as 4 × 3?' (Yes!) Have them draw arrays to prove it.
outline.exit_ticket: Students draw an array or groups to match a multiplication sentence.

3-mathematics-number-and-operations-plac.title: Place Value (thousands/millions)
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-plac.summary: Understand the value of digits in numbers. Work with thousands, millions, and other place values.
objectives: Identify place value of digits (ones, tens, hundreds, thousands, etc.)
Read and write numbers in expanded form
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-plac.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Write 345. Ask: 'What does the 4 represent?' (40) 'The 3?' (300) Discuss how the same digit means different amounts.
outline.direct_instruction: Each place is 10 times the place to its right. Ones, tens, hundreds, thousands. Show with place value blocks or charts.
outline.guided_practice: Write numbers in expanded form: 234 = 200 + 30 + 4. Compare numbers using place value. Round to nearest 10 or 100.
outline.independent_practice: Students identify place values in numbers. Write numbers in expanded form. Compare numbers and round.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'What is 5 in 5,432?' (5 thousands, or 5,000) 'Is 234 or 324 bigger?'
outline.exit_ticket: Students write a number in expanded form or identify the place value of one digit.

3-mathematics-number-and-operations-roun.title: Rounding & Estimation
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-roun.summary: Round numbers to the nearest 10, 100, or 1000. Estimate sums and differences using rounding.
objectives: Round numbers to different place values
Understand when and why to round
3-mathematics-number-and-operations-roun.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Ask: 'Is 48 closer to 40 or 50?' Show a number line. Round 48 to 50. Explain using a number line.
outline.direct_instruction: Look at the digit to the right of the place you're rounding to. If 5 or more, round up. If less than 5, round down.
outline.guided_practice: Round several numbers together: 23 to nearest 10, 156 to nearest 100. Use number lines.
outline.independent_practice: Students round 8-10 numbers to specified place values. Estimate sums by rounding first.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'What is 67 rounded to the nearest 10?' 'Is that reasonable?' Have them explain their thinking.
outline.exit_ticket: Students round 2 numbers and optionally estimate a sum.

outline.direct_instruction: Translation: slide a shape without rotating or flipping. Rotation: turn a shape around a point. Reflection: flip a shape over a line.
outline.guided_practice: Using cut-out shapes and mirrors, demonstrate each transformation. Have students copy and predict what happens.
outline.independent_practice: Students perform transformations on grid paper. Draw a triangle, then show it translated right, rotated 90°, and reflected.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'If I translate a square, is it still a square?' 'How is a reflection different from a rotation?'
outline.exit_ticket: Students identify the transformation shown and describe it (e.g., 'Slide 3 units right').

8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.title: Volume & Surface Area
8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.summary: Measure how much space objects take up. Calculate volume of rectangular prisms using unit cubes and formulas.
objectives: Count unit cubes to find volume
Use the formula length × width × height
Solve volume problems with real objects
8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-v.subject: Mathematics

outline.hook: Fill a small box with unit cubes. Count them together. Explain: this number is the volume—how much space is inside.
outline.direct_instruction: Volume is measured in cubic units (cm³, in³). Fill a rectangular prism with cubes and count. Or multiply: length × width × height.
outline.guided_practice: Build rectangular prisms with cubes and count the volume together. Try different dimensions. See how volume changes.
outline.independent_practice: Students build 3-4 different rectangular prisms and calculate volume by counting cubes and by formula.
outline.check_for_understanding: Ask: 'If I double the height, what happens to volume?' Have them test.
outline.exit_ticket: Given dimensions, students calculate volume or count cubes for a provided figure.
